messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> If your accent merges two sounds, you must use just one QS letter and
> not attempt to use the other.

I don't think that's practical. We learn huge numbers of words by reading
them rather than by hearing them; even if you have an Ox-Ah merger like
me (and most North Americans), if you first run into the word "oddball"
in a British book, you may very well learn it with Ox.

> Presumably the QS letter to choose is the one whose RP sound most
> closely resembles your unified sound.

I'm talking only about mergers here, where the members of two different
lexical sets are pronounced the same way. That has completely different
effects from vowel shifts, where there is a systematic set of changes
in how various lexical sets are pronounced.

(There are also splits, where a lexical set divides into two
different pronunciations, but QS just can't handle those at all.)

> If an Australian spells "accent" with a different initial vowel,

A New Zealander, and it's *both* vowels. Every single short vowel is
different in the Southern Hemisphere, and likewise in large parts of
the U.S. (Other Americans don't really notice the Inland North accent
as special: our ears adjust automatically and we don't see how different
it really is.)

> it is just one letter out of 6 in one word out of 50 and is unimportant.

Au contraire. Hundreds of thousands of words are affected.

> - It freezes QS spelling so changes in pronunciation will never be
> reflected in writing. One is just creating a new TO with letters of a
> different shape which is a pointless exercise.

Not at all. A huge number of old mergers (meet/meat, vain/vein) are
disposed of, as well as gobs of pointless irregularities that have never
meant anything to anybody.

> - One has the absurd situation of answering the question "why do I
> spell it thus" with "because TO does and TO does it because in 13th
> century London the queen had a lisp".

(That story is about Spanish, not English, and it's not true anyway.
Just sayin'.)

> - You base QS spelling on TO words that themselves may change. eg
> color vs colour

That has never represented a distinction in pronunciation. Noah Webster
standardized the U.S. on "color" because he thought it was absurd to
have some words in "-or" and some in "-our", with neither a historical
nor a phonetic basis for it. The only pity is that the innovation
didn't spread.

> - There are exceptions to any such rules that will cause QS users to
> produce exactly the wrong result: if a person merging [I] and [i] is
> told to "use #26 for words of that sound that have a TO letter 'i' in
> the spelling and use #27 for all others with that sound" then they
> will spell "busy" and "bean" with the same letter. in this case "busy"
> with [i] something not done in RP or anywhere. But if you reveres the
> instructions the problem now exists with "bean"

So it does, by Goerge [sic]. I don't know what anyone can do about that.
If you can't hear the difference, you're going to make misteaks.

> Still it looks like Lexical set's are quite usable in a solution,

At least we are no longer talking about "phonomes". :-)
